bestBHT.bht: After Jesus died, Pilate was likely relieved to have him off his hands and to have Joseph take care of the burial. It was unusual for Jesus' body to be referred to as a corpse, considering the word cadaver is only used for dead bodies. The centurion confirmed Jesus' death, and Pilate, satisfied with the report, gave the body to Joseph. This official confirmation was necessary before the burial.

Henry Alford: The passage cited from Cicero to shew that it was customary to give money on such occasions, is not to the point...
...'the parents were obliged to purchase with money a speedy death,' is not said of the body after death...
...but of a fee given to the officer for shortening the torments of the executed.
Albert Barnes: When he knew it of the centurion - Being informed by the centurion of the fact that he was dead.
The centurion had charge of the soldiers who watched him, and could therefore give correct information.
Marvin Vincent: Body [πτωμα] . Better, Rev., corpse; as the word is used only of a dead body. See on Matthew 24:28.
Philip Schaff: Granted the corpse to Joseph. Presented it to him.
The position of Joseph seems to have occasioned this ready compliance.
Pilate was doubtless glad to hear that Jesus was dead and to have Him buried.
Archibald T. Robertson: This is the only instance when πτωμα (cadaver, corpse) is applied to the body (σωμα) of Jesus."
As a matter of fact Pilate was probably glad to turn the body over to Joseph else the body would go to the potter's field."
This official information was necessary before the burial.
John Gill: And when he knew it of the centurion...with which Pilate being satisfied..." (approx. 34 words)
Who might inform him of his giving up the ghost...so that there was no room to doubt of his being really dead..." (approx. 30 words)
...he gave the body to Joseph; ordered it to be given to him; gave him leave to take it down from the cross, and inter it." (approx. 26 words)

bhtAttempts.bht: After Jesus died, Pilate was likely relieved to have him off his hands and to have Joseph take care of the burial. It was unusual for Jesus' body to be referred to as a corpse, considering the word cadaver is only used for dead bodies. The centurion confirmed Jesus' death, and Pilate, satisfied with the report, gave the body to Joseph. This official confirmation was necessary before the burial.

After Jesus died, Pilate was probably glad to turn the body over to Joseph, else it would have gone to the potter's field. The centurion, who had charge of the soldiers watching Jesus, informed Pilate of his death, allowing him to give the body to Joseph. It is worth noting that it is quite unusual for Jesus' body to be referred to as a corpse, as the word is only used for dead bodies. This official information was necessary before the burial could occur.

After Jesus died, Pilate was likely relieved to have him off his hands and to have Joseph take care of the burial. It was unusual for Jesus' body to be referred to as a corpse, considering the word cadaver is only used for dead bodies. The centurion confirmed Jesus' death, and Pilate, satisfied with the report, gave the body to Joseph. This official confirmation was necessary before the burial.

Pilate, upon receiving confirmation from the centurion, granted Joseph permission to take down Jesus' body from the cross. Being informed of Jesus' death, Pilate was likely relieved to have Joseph take care of the burial. It is worth noting that it is quite unusual for Jesus' body to be referred to as a corpse, as the word cadaver is only used for dead bodies. Pilate's compliance was facilitated by Joseph's position, and this official information was necessary for the proper burial to proceed.

Pilate, after being informed by the centurion of Jesus' death, granted Joseph permission to take down Jesus' body from the cross. Pilate was likely relieved to have Joseph handle the burial, and it is notable that Jesus' body was referred to as a corpse, a term exclusively used for dead bodies. Joseph's position may have influenced Pilate's ready compliance, and this official confirmation was necessary before the burial could proceed.
